title: What are the examples of cutting edge technology public doesn't know about? - Quora

response.answer_text: Easy! The military use tech that is 10 to 20 years ahead of consumer and commercial use, assuming it ever makes it to those markets. So for the time it is in use exclusively by the military, chances are, the public won't know unless observing in confidence. Two examples, both of which are now in the public domain: Plasma flat screens - Warships in the early 1980s had futuristic at the time plasma screens that didn't make it into laptops and then TVs (in colour for the latter) until the early noughties. I believe the Grid Compass was the first laptop with one.Virtual transparent cockpit- Probably one of the coolest technologies ever developed in my opinion. Don an F35 pilot helmet when in flight and look around. You will be able to look right through the aircraft body at the terrain below as if the fuselage wasn't there or made of a transparent material! How does it work? No, not cameras on the aircraft, that would not allow the crew to see through poor weather or in darkness. The US military has a high resolution 3D model of the Earth and projects the appropriate area onto the helmet visor in real time. Cool or what? Now the clincher! The B2 stealth bomber had this - back in the early 1990s! How do I know? I met a disaffected software engineer in California in about 1992 who worked on it and who probably broke the US secrets act in telling me, but I kept it mum until this week after reading about the F35 version in a public article just yesterday, June 7 2019. (I was interviewing the engineer with regards to developing a live 3D Earth globe to do what Google Earth does now, but even better. He effectively was telling me it had already been done - by the military.) For those interested, almost 20 years since I had the idea for a live 3D globe, my employer is now developing it, our way, it's already looking cool. Yup, going up against the big G. We have some cool ideas, so why not? Anyway, re the original question, sorry that neither of these examples are secret anymore, so less intriguing, but you can be assured that there will be all manner of magical tech in use or in development from handheld laser weapons to fly sized spy drones to stealth (‘invisible man’) army clothing etc.

He was dismissed from the hospital for political reasons and harassed by the medical community in Vienna, being eventually forced to move to Budapest. Semmelweis was outraged by the indifference of the medical profession and began writing open and increasingly angry letters to prominent European drs at times denouncing them as irresponsible murderers. His contemporaries, including his wife, believed he was losing his mind, and in 1865, nearly twenty years after his breakthrough, he was committed to an asylum.
